LJava
Class LJ

java.lang.Object
  LJava.LJ

public class LJ
extends java.lang.Object

This class is meant to create all the script-power behind the logical engine of LJava. It holds many static attributes and methods so the user can write his program without having to take care of objects. This is true for all objects besides Variable which requires a declaration with the 'new' command.

Author:
Tzali Maimon

Parameters:
args - Arguments of the new relation.

exists

public static boolean exists(Relation r)
Runs a giving relation to compare with the engine's database and satisfy any given variables in the given relation if possible. Every variable is satisfied to have a single value. This means that if a solution to all variables was found, no more solutions are searched. A care should be taken when using this method. For example: If a Variable x is instantiated as Variable y, then the engine will fill in whatever is in y into x even if it occurs later. But if y will be then instantiated to be x, then a logical chain occurs since the solution of x is y and the solution of y is x. In this case the engine will return the special relation nil() into both variables. This will occur with any logical chain. But If x will be instantiated into a class named A which contains a attribute of type Variable y which in turn will be later instantiated to x, then a StackOverFlowException will occur. Because of that, any use of Variables inside a different wrapper should be carefully considered. You should also note that it is possible to place a variable inside a relate command and so to place an non deterministic fact in the DB: relate(1,2,x); Then place another relate: (3,4,5) and performing exists(3,x,5) will instantiate x as 4 and thus creating the fact (1,2,4) in the DB. Note that this method will return true if written exists(true) and false if written exists(false).

Parameters:
r - A given relation to compare with the engine's database
Returns:
A boolean expression true if the relation was satisfied, otherwise false.

exists

public static boolean exists(Relation r,
                             VariableValuesMap varValues)
This method performs as exists only it doesn't instantiate the variables. It returns a map which holds all variables and their possible values.

Parameters:
r - A relation to research.
varValues - A given map that will hold the values.
Returns:
A boolean expression if the map was changed.

exists

public static boolean exists(java.lang.Object... args)
Runs a nameless relation to compare with the engine's database and satisfy any given variables in the given relation if possible. Every variable is satisfied to have a single value. See further notes in the exists(Relation r) definition.

Parameters:
args - Arguments of the nameless relation.
Returns:
A boolean expression true if the arguments were satisfied, otherwise false.

conduct

public static boolean conduct(Relation r)
Conducts a full DB scan to find all solution for the given relation. It will place all possible values to each of the variables in the relation. You should note that if there are no variables in the relation then this will be equals to using exists(r) but conduct(r) is much more expensive in runtime terms.

Parameters:
r - A relation to conduct a research on.
Returns:
A boolean expression. Returns True if succeeded to conduct any solution.

conduct

public static boolean conduct(Relation r,
                              VariableValuesMap varValues)
Acts just like conduct only it returns the results into a VAriableValuesMap without instantiating any of the variables in the relation.

Parameters:
r - A given relation
varValues - A map to fill with the returned values.
Returns:
true if succeeded in returning any value to all the variables in the relation.

conduct

public static boolean conduct(java.lang.Object... args)
This allows the user to avoid wrapping a relation in order to conduct. See conduct(Relation r) description for more details.

Parameters:
args - Arguments
Returns:
A boolean expression.

same

public static boolean same(java.lang.Object a,
                           java.lang.Object b)
Compares between objects. If one of the objects is a Variable then it activates Variable.equals(Object) which has a different result then Object.equals(Object). See the Variable.equals description for more details.

Parameters:
a - An object
b - An object
Returns:
True if equals.

query

public static boolean query(VariableValuesMap varValues)
This method activates logical operators given in its arguments. For example: query(and(or(a,b), or(a,c))); where a,b,c are relations.

Parameters:
varValues - A varValuesMap
Returns:
A boolean expression. True if an assignment was successful on all the variables in all the relations in the query under the logical operators.

map

public static VariableValuesMap map(QueryParameter x)
Maps all the values in the given QueryParameter x. If it is already a map of values then it returns x. if it's a relation it performs conduct on it and return the map of values of that conduct but without instantiating the variables in the relation.

Parameters:
x - a giving QueryParameter
Returns:
a variables value map.

nil

public static Relation nil()

Returns:
the nil Relation
